page.title: 16Maidensgrove Coal Charity
page.content: At the time of the Enclosures Acts in the early 19th century, part of Maidensgrove Common was enclosed. Before that the people of Watlington could graze geese and pigs on the land and collect firewood. When the land was cleared and let for farming, the rents were used to buy coal for the poor of the parish in lieu of firewood. Anyone living in the parish of Watling- ton and paying less than ten pounds per year in rates could claim this coal. The fields are still owned by the Trust and are leased for farming. Some years ago however a cottage on the land was sold and the proceeds invested. The rents and interest are used to buy coal. In 1984 due to a miners strike, money was paid out; 14 pounds being distributed to each of approx. 150 beneficiaries consisting of widowers, widows and old age pensioners.
